entry.et: Middle English, from Anglo-French bai, from Latin badius; akin to Old Irish buide yellow

def.dt: :reddish brown a bay mare
:a bay-colored animal
:a horse with a bay-colored body and black mane, tail, and points compare chestnut 4 sorrel 1
:a reddish brown

entry.et: Middle English, from Anglo-French baee opening, from feminine of baé, past participle of baer to be wide open, gape, from Vulgar Latin *batare

def.dt: :a principal compartment of the walls, roof, or other part of a building or of the whole building
:a main division of a structure
:any of various compartments or sections used for a special purpose (as in an airplane, spacecraft, or service station) a bomb bay a cargo bay
:bay window 1
:a support or housing for electronic equipment

entry.et: Middle English baien, abaien, from Anglo-French abaier, of imitative origin

def.dt: :to bark with prolonged tones dogs baying at the moon
:to cry out :shout
:to bark at
:to bring to bay
:to pursue with barking
:to utter in deep prolonged tones
:a baying of dogs
:the position of one unable to retreat and forced to face danger brought his quarry to bay
:the position of one checked police kept the rioters at bay

entry.et: Middle English baye, from Anglo-French bai, perhaps from baer to be wide open

def.dt: :an inlet of the sea or other body of water usually smaller than a gulf
:a small body of water set off from the main body
:any of various terrestrial formations resembling a bay of the sea

entry.et: Middle English, berry, laurel berry, from Anglo-French bai, from L. baca

def.dt: :laurel 1
:any of several shrubs or trees (as the red bay or sweet bay) resembling the laurel compare bay rum
:a garland or crown especially of laurel given as a prize for victory or excellence
:honor fame usually used in plural
:the dried leaf of the European laurel (Laurus nobilis) used in cooking
:a fragrant cosmetic and medicinal liquid distilled from the leaves of a West Indian bay tree (Pimenta racemosa) of the myrtle family or usually prepared from essential oils, alcohol, and water
:a scallop (Argopecten irradians) of United States coastal and estuarine waters of the Atlantic Ocean and the Gulf of Mexico that is harvested commercially for food
